hobby.message: Antique typewriters and quiet bars — good pair.
Still dodging towers with those drones?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Thicker, yes. Less clear days lately.
Better to stay indoors, work with my typewriters.
Mechanical work keeps me occupied.
Harder to concentrate with all this commotion lately.
Could be thicker, or maybe it's just the mood these days.
I fix old typewriters at home—less noticeable than most activities.
Noticed neighbors outdoing each other for BCI points, all that noise seeps in.
Restoring antiques is slower with so many distractions now.
Best to keep to the older routines, I think.
Thick enough to make you think twice, I suppose.
I spend my hours with antique typewriters—restoration is my habit.
Some days it's the only thing that feels unchanged.
The recent 'Empathy Outbreak' had folks at my building running repair drives.
Funny how it affected even my restoration time—couldn't escape the buzz.
Paper and ink are quieter company than crowds performing kindness.
Feels heavier, yes. Or maybe that's just me noticing more lately.
I restore old typewriters—mechanical, tactile, keeps the world at arm's length.
Last week, everyone staged 'good deeds' for BCI boosts, organizing communal fix-its.
Felt strange joining in; I prefer solitary repairs, no audience.
Even my apartment's quiet hobby corner wasn't immune to the city’s mood swings.
I found myself double-checking the 'intent' behind repairing a carriage.
Habit now, making sure every key I press stays private.
The smoke's thicker, or our eyes are finally stinging from all these performances.
I spend hours on old typewriters—restoring, cataloguing, keeping pieces of the past alive.
Handwriting in my journal matters more than a hundred cheerful digital posts.
The city’s BCI 'Empathy Outbreak' had neighbors performing kindness, half for points, half for show.
It even reached my doorstep: folks asking if I’d set up a repair stall for public credit.
Didn’t sit right—my typewriter time is private, wordless, not for broadcasting scores.
A single page typed at midnight feels more honest than all the staged goodwill outside.
Sometimes I lock away my journals, not out of fear—just to have something untouched by the system.
hobby_answer: Yes, managed to get the shift key working again.
Restoring these old machines is reliable—unless the city notices.
Too much attention on small things these days.
Neighbors stage 'kindness' for points; I keep quietly to my desk.
Best to keep old habits private while the system's watching.
Yes, it prints clearly now after some work.
Not many left who appreciate manual typing.
Lately, everyone wants to be seen 'helping' for BCI boosts.
Makes real hobbies feel almost subversive, oddly enough.
I stay away from those group repair tables.
People perform for the score, not out of real interest.
Yes, I finally got the ribbon threading just right last night.
Restoring typewriters is steady, unlike the mood outside.
The whole 'Empathy Outbreak'—I've seen neighbors faking helpfulness for BCI points.
It’s harder to know who genuinely cares about anything these days.
Used to be, I’d fix a neighbor’s keys for the sake of it.
Now it feels like every act is another entry on a ledger.
I’ve taken to working at odd hours, fewer eyes around.
Yes, the Continental’s working—took a steady hand and some patience.
When I restore these, it’s supposed to be for peace, not points.
Since they started rewarding public kindness, everything feels a bit off-kilter.
Last week, neighbors organized a repair table downstairs, mostly for the system to ‘notice.’
I almost joined in, but couldn’t shake the sense of being evaluated.
You see, they even prompt for ‘genuine intent’ now in requests.
That’s enough to make me type late at night, out of sight.
Funny—a world that claims to value empathy but turns it into performance.
Yes, finally fixed the old Continental—the bell’s tone is perfect now.
I started restoring typewriters years before all this surveillance nonsense.
Used to swap tips with a neighbor, just for the craft of it.
Now, after that empathy protocol update, every favor feels like theater.
Last weekend, folks downstairs put on a big show of repairs—hardly anyone cared about the machines.
I deleted my grocery record after a prompt asked why I helped someone last month.
Handwritten pages feel safer than any message in the city right now.
Sometimes I worry they’ll start scoring us for the ‘tone’ in our repair logs.
So I stick to typebars and ink, doors locked, pretending it’s still just a hobby.
